testimony: You may be seated.  Mr Visser.

Thank you, Chairperson.
	Mr Robertshaw, I just want to make this clear, you are not either Robert or Shaw, you're Robertshaw, is that correct?

You filed an application and you're an applicant in the amnesty applications which are presently serving before this Amnesty Committee, and your amnesty application is to be found in the bundle at page 16 to 22, is that correct?
Subject to your evidence here today, do you confirm the truthfulness and the correctness of the contents of that amnesty application?

You also - on your behalf was drawn a statement of the evidence that you will give before this Committee, in order to be of assistance to the Committee, and that is pages 22A to C of the same bundle, is that correct?

At page 22A, you refer to the General Background document, which we know very well at this stage, and you told me, is that correct, that except for the references to Botswana and Swaziland, you are able to confirm from your own knowledge and experience, the broad background set out in that document, is that correct?
And you ask that that be incorporated when your application for amnesty is considered by this Committee.

Mr Robertshaw, you at page 16, under paragraph 17A and B, the answers given there are "not applicable, not applicable" - Chairperson, it just occurred to me that although I'm sure Mr Lax and Mr Sibanyoni has heard this before, but I don't think anybody's ever given you personally an explanation as to how it came about that in all the applications of almost all of the applicants of Mr Wagener, these answers were given as "not applicable, not applicable".  And there's a simple answer to that, Chairperson, an explanation, and that is, Mr Wagener read the question incorrectly and we gave the other Committees, before we appeared, this explanation and it has been accepted.  But clearly, Chairperson, instead of interpreting that question restrictively, it should have been interpreted widely as including members, supporters and everything, Chairperson.  So we would ask you to allow paragraph 7A to read
"National Party"
and 7B, to read:
"Supporter"

Thank you, Chairperson.
	Is that correct, Mr Robertshaw?

Now Mr Robertshaw, perhaps if we can forget about the papers for the moment, can you give the Committee - first of all, you joined the Security Branch at Ladybrand in 1986, according to your amnesty application, is that correct?
And what was your status at Ladybrand, in the Security Police?
I was second-in-charge of the branch in Ladybrand.
And who was your commanding officer, the Branch Commander?
And at some stage you became involved with the gathering of information, is that correct?
Was that from the beginning, or did that happen a little later on?
That was from the beginning, Mr Chairper-son.
So when you were transferred to Ladybrand, you immediately became involved in the gathering of information?
Now, do you recall from your own knowledge and recollection, when the incidents, the events took place which led to the present application for amnesty?
That happened towards the end of 1987.
1987.  When you say "towards the end", can you be more specific?
The last few months before the end of the year.
Yes.  Now just give the Committee a sense of how your - if I may refer to it as a unit, it wasn't really a unit or was it?
It was a section, I'd refer to it as a section.
How did you work with this section, how did you go about things?  Can you just tell the Committee, give us a sense of your day to day basis of how you operated.

Well the section referred to was basically responsible for the gathering of information in Lesotho, concerning mainly the PAC and the ANC, so these people had to concentrate on that work.  They would - we'd come together on an ad hoc basis, if they had information about something that had transpired in Lesotho, something that they had brought to my attention, they'd come into my office, we'd discuss it, I'd tell them what to do with the information, put it into report form, get more information, whatever the case was.  It wasn't - there weren't so-called formal meetings about this whole thing, it was conducted on a day to day basis.
And when you say they would come to your office, would they always come together, all three of them or would they sometimes comes separately?

No, not at all, they'd come separately, they'd come together.  For instance, if W/O Jagga and Jantjie had been to Lesotho and they'd gathered information, then perhaps only Jagga would come to me office, sometimes they'd together, sometimes one of them would come.  It wasn't a specified meeting that I'd had with them.
My attorney is just passing a note to the witness to go a little bit slower, Chairperson.
I noticed that the past was reduced.

Was there any reason - you see, let me put it to you this way, Mr Thulo seemed to have given the impression that he was excluded from certain inner circle discussions about information that was gathered in Lesotho, was that the position?

Can you remember today from your own recollection, your meetings not having been formal minuted meetings, who attended gatherings, each gathering for example in regard to the present four victims when discussions took place about them?
No, I cannot remember that, Chairperson.
So if Mr Thulo says that he was not present when Ms Betty Boom was discussed, can you argue with that?
I'm in no position to argue with that.
But it wouldn't have been because he was intentionally excluded?
Now Mr Robertshaw, you were personally involved only in the fetching of two of these people, is that correct?
You heard the evidence about how it came about that Betty Boom was recruited as an informer.
And does that evidence accord with your recollection of what you were told at the time?
And also as far as the others are concerned?
Alright.  Now perhaps just answer this, why did you go along in the instance of two of these people and not in the instance of all four of them?

Chairperson, my position was being their Commander in the first place, I was involved with their activities as far as I was able to.  I enjoyed going out with them, it was - I didn't like being caught up in an office and it was also for moral support.  I saw it as part of my work and part of my duties and it happened that way.
Can you recall the day when Ms Betty Boom was fetched?
I recall - I don't remember the exact date, but I recall the incident.
Can you just give us a brief sketch of your recollection of that incident that day.

We entered Lesotho through the Maseru border post.  We drove to - I don't know the area, the different areas in Lesotho, but we drove quite some way into Maseru, and we stopped alongside the road and a female entered the vehicle and we drove back.
It was as simple as that?
It was basically as simple as that.
Mr Jantjie was under some impression about a proposed abduction of Ms Betty Boom, does that accord with your recollection?
That's what we discussed yes, it is my recollection.
How would the abduction issue have worked, would you have to go and make it appear as an abduction, or would that only enter the picture later?

If something - basically, if there were other people that would witness the occasion, or if we'd received information later on that she's been seen in our presence we would have let the word go out that she'd been abducted.
And would that have been to give her a cover, to justify her absence to her own organisation?
And this whole issue of the farm, can you just tell us what you know about this farm, when you started using it, for how long you used it, and how it came about that this farm was being used.

This farm was only used for this occasion, these occurrences that have been heard by this Commission.  I'm not aware of that farm having been used for any other occasion.  To the best of my recollection, it was W/O Jagga that organised the farm.  We didn't have that farm at our disposal for longer than three or four months, as far as I can remember.
Mr Jagga said two months, do you disagree with his reckoning of the time that you had it?  I think he said November and December.
Is your recollection that it might have been longer?
It might have been longer, yes.
Alright.  But this whole affair with the four present victims, took no more than a week at a time?
The first three took a week.
And KK took a day or two, isn't that correct?
I'm not - probably a day or two, I'm not quite sure if it was a day or two.
Alright, well make it a week.  So in other words, you actually used the farm for approximately two weeks, is that correct?

Sorry Mr Visser, who's testifying here, you or him?  I mean you're leading him with times and so on, let him tell us what his recollection is, rather than you suggesting to him what the time periods are.  Please.

I was trying to make it short, I didn't think it was that important.
	How long did you use this farm in total?
You said in your statement that you're unable to recall each and every meeting, but that you were aware of all the actions taken by the three persons in your section, is that correct?

May I ask you, as far as the evidence is concerned that this Committee has heard, was there anything that they did, as far as you are concerned, that conflicted with any of your instructions to them or with what you expected of them?
Not that I'm aware of, Chairperson.
May I then on that score immediately ask you about Mr Ngono.  At the time that Mr Ngono was discussed, can you recall precisely who were present at that, let's call it a meeting?
No, I can't recall precisely, Chairperson.
And can you recall what your instructions were in regard to Mr Ngono?
I told them that they must attempt to recruit him, if that failed, then they must attempt to abduct him.
Was it your intention that that instruction should mean that they should follow specifically that sequence of the order?
Was it your intention that it was an alternative order?
When you heard when they came back that there was not attempt to recruit Ngono in Lesotho, did you consider for a moment that that was a breach of your order that you gave them?
And you accepted that what they had done was in the proper execution of the order which you'd given?
Now at this meeting where Mr Ngono was discussed, we know from the evidence of Mr Jagga that there was a file available on Mr Ngono, to which the Security Branch had access, is that correct?
Do you remember whether that file was available at the time of your meeting or meetings about Mr Ngono, and whether reference was made to the background of this person, in the file?

Chairperson, I don't know if - we're coming back to the meeting as well, I don't know if the file was ... at the time that we were discussing this, but the file would have been available in our filing room if we had wanted it.
Although you can't remember whether it was physically present at the time when you spoke about it?

Alright.  Mr Robertshaw, give the Committee the benefit how you saw your position in the Security Police during the conflict of the past and how you saw your duties, in relationship to this application for amnesty.
I'm not sure I can understand the question completely, Chairperson.
Well when you gave these orders, did you give it from a personal perspective or what did you think you were doing?

I gave these orders specifically as a result of the position that I was in, of the circumstances of the day, that we were actually - my impression was that we were involved in an actual war with these people and that we would have to do anything in our capabilities to try and stop what was going on, what the ANC were trying to do.
Was it your aim to protect the interests of the South African Government at the time?
And who was the majority shareholder of the government of the time?
It was the National Party, Mr Chairman.
Now do you have knowledge of the consequences of any information that might have been received from Ms Betty Boom?
Do you know whether information regarding the activities of MK, was received from Ms Betty Boom?
Is this prior to her being brought to Ladybrand, or at ...
The information that she supplied us with?
Yes, she supplied us with information about MK activities in and outside Lesotho.
You heard the evidence of Mr Jagga?
I heard the evidence of Mr Jagga.
And he mentioned a name of a person in Bloemfontein, is that right?
He mentioned the name, Makanda.  It's almost like Makanda.  I can't remember the correct name of that person.
Yes.  It may be Kapanda, it's something that sounds like that.
Yes Chairperson, I have no further evidence-in-chief from this witness.
Chairperson, could I just say something please?
In my statement, paragraph 3 on - I don't know which ...(indistinct) reads - it's 22B in paragraph 3 ...(intervention)
Could you just bear with me for a moment.  22B?

22B, paragraph 3.  I'll read it
"I have read the evidence of Jantjie and fully agree with his testimony about the events of these incidents."
I'd just like to add there:
"as far as I'm concerned"
Do you mean to say in as far as he refers to you?  Is that what you're saying.
That's correct, that's what I'm trying to say.
And in incorporating Jantjie's evidence, you incorporated the statement, not his evidence that he gave?
In fact, while you're on that score, do you agree with everything that Mr Jantjie told this Committee?
No, I don't agree with everything that he told the Committee, Chairperson.

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR VISSER
Thank you, Mr Visser.  Mr Malindi, are you taking the queue?

Thank you, Chairperson, I will continue with this witness.
	Mr Robertshaw, would you agree that Thulo's evidence amounts to saying that he was not allowed into the interrogation room where Betty Boom, Nomasonto Mashiya and Tax Sejanamane were being interrogated?

Mr Chairperson, I don't know if we can refer to it as an interrogation room, she was being debriefed, basically, in a room at the farm.  If he was not allowed in there - I wasn't there all the time, so I can't give an answer to that.
And he also indicated that sometimes within the section there are things that he wouldn't know about and he wouldn't even ask about them and that was the way things worked.

I never excluded any information from him wilfully.  If he wasn't present when certain things were discussed, then he might interpret it as if we hadn't told him, but it was never done wilfully to excluded him from anything.

And with that evidence in mind and him having only last seen the victims that are the subject of this enquiry, at the farm, it gives the impression that he last saw them on the farm when they were being put in that room where they were being questioned or debriefed or interrogated, and he never saw them again.  That's the gist of his evidence, do you agree?
I agree with that.  I don't know if he saw them after that, he might have seen them in Lesotho, I'm not sure.
Well his evidence is he last saw them on the farm.  That was his answer to one of the Committee Member's question.
Do you agree with the evidence so far, that you had information about Betty Boom's cell and you had information that they were preparing to launch attacks into the Free State, in particular?

And as a section gathering intelligence, your role would have been to alert the relevant security arm, to either arrest them when they go out on this mission, or to intercept them or something to that effect, is it not so?
Chairperson, are we talking in general now, or are we talking specifically about this?
That is correct, Chairperson, that was one of our tasks, amongst others.
And will it be fair to say in this instance, you had enough information to alert other Security Forces to effect arrests, at least, upon this unit of Betty Boom's?
I don't follow the gist of the question, can you clarify please?  I'm not sure.

Sure.  If your role was to gather information and to pass it on to relevant arms of the Security Forces, and one of those arms would - I think you would agree with me, the Security Forces that will effect arrests upon people that you've gathered information on, when they launched attacks into South Africa.  What I'm suggesting is that you had enough information to ensure that this whole unit is arrested if and when they launched attacks into the Free State.  You agree with me?
If we had the information that they were going to launch attacks into the Free State and they did that, then we would take measures to arrest them or prevent them from doing so.

In the applications before the Committee, there's reference that you had knowledge that this unit was about to launch attacks during the Xmas period, into the Free State.  Did you have that information yourself?
If we have a look at - you're talking about this unit, you're talking about Betty Boom's unit?
Yes, they had people inside the Republic, the people inside the Republic were going to commit these attacks.  It wasn't that they were going to come out of Lesotho and commit the attacks.
Well at a later stage I think I'll refer to the applications which clearly indicate that this unit was going to launch attacks.
How wide is - the question is, how wide was the unit?  How big was it?  How many people belonged to the unit?

Well one application form, I think it's Jantjie's application form, it first says the unit consisted of three people and then in the supplementary papers it says it consisted of four people.  Is that your information that you had?

Well if one looks at page 9 of Jantjie's application, which all associate yourselves with, the second paragraph from the bottom, which reads - the second sentence
"By means of informers we were informed that she was a Commander of an MK cell which was responsible for the launching of terrorist operations from Lesotho to the RSA"
I read that to say this unit which is inside Lesotho was responsible for coming into the Republic and launching attacks.  Do you agree with me?
Just let me read it again please.  I read it differently, Chairperson.

Well if you read it
"By means of informers we were informed that she was a Commander of an MK cell which was responsible for launching terrorist operations from Lesotho to the RSA, and more specifically the Free State."
I don't read that to say that they were going to infiltrate and they were going to ... they had to organise.
Maybe it will be a question of argument on how that sentence should be interpreted.
The next sentence does go on to say that though that it's dealing - you're talking about the cell?
Yes.  This is the cell that they're talking about.
And the cell is the subject of the sentence, not Betty Boom.
And therefore it's the cell that's responsible for the attacks.
The cell is responsible, that's correct Chairperson.

My suggestion is that you had enough information that this cell was going to launch attacks in the RSA, in particular in the Free State, all you had to do was to inform other sections of the Security Forces, they could have arrested the whole of this unit, which must have been their main objective of securing the country at the time.
No, you didn't arrest the unit, you in fact tried to re-transform the unit and make it all informers, instead of arresting them.  Which was the more effective way of dealing with...

Chairperson, we utilised the information and when utilising that information this person that we've referred to before was killed in Bloemfontein.  There were also other people killed in a roadblock in Bloemfontein.  That was a result of the information that we'd received from the cell.
	If I can just carry on on that, Chairperson, we had information that they wanted to attack the, well bomb the Army offices in Maitland Street as well and that was also, guards were placed to guard the area so that didn't take place.

Well the previous witnesses, if I remember well, could only remember the incident involving Tony Yengeni and the other person that you referred to in-chief, in Bloemfontein, and both incidents that we ...(indistinct) verify at this stage, isn't it?
I'm telling you what I remembered, Mr Chairperson.
You say that the discussions about abductions you were aware of, but at the end of the day these people were not abducted, that's Betty Boom, Nomasonto and Tax.

Betty Boom wasn't abducted, Chairperson, but - I don't know if it would amount to abduction if you took somebody out of a country and took away their freedom by false pretences, I'm not au fait with the law in that respect.
You agree with the previous witnesses, that they were not forced into these vehicles that fetched them, they actually came in willingly, voluntarily?
I can only speak on behalf of two of them, Chairperson, and that was Betty Boom and Tax Sejanamane.
The ones that you were involved with?
But the question remains, you've given a reason for initially wanting it to appear as kidnapping, as an abduction, why at the end didn't you effect that?
Why didn't you make it look like an abduction, for the reasons that you gave in-chief?
Why did we not do it?

Well the evidence is that you sent them back into Lesotho in order to operate as informers, and the reason why you wanted it to appear as an abduction initially, was so that if anybody saw them being taken away they wouldn't suspect that they were being taken away because they co-operated with you.
Chairperson, you're referring to they, who are you referring to?
I'm referring to the Betty Boom unit.
The cell.  Okay let's deal with one person at a time and let's start from the outset.  Initially you wanted it to appear as an abduction, when you took or fetched Betty Boom from Lesotho.

My learned friend has said that three times now, Chairperson, and that's not the evidence.  The evidence was that initially it was supposed to be an abduction, that was Jantjie's evidence, that's not this witness's evidence.  This witness says if it would become necessary later, if it appeared that people either saw them or that there were suspicions, they would then use it as a cover to put out the word that she was abducted, in order for her to have a cover to back to the ANC.  That was this witness's evidence.  He never said that it was supposed to be a pretended abduction from the word go, that was not his evidence.

Except to say that he did say that the initial plan was to make it look like an abduction, if there were people in the vicinity and then later, if it later appeared that they were seen.  Now those are two slightly contradictory versions, but be it as it may, I'll clarify that with him in due course.  But the fact of the matter is that all the witnesses, all the applicants in essence, were under the impression that the object of the exercise was to effect a purported abduction if, if there were people in the vicinity.
Yes, that is correct, Chairperson.  Or if there would be problems later.
Well you couldn't do it, you couldn't conduct an abduction ex post facto when you've already taken the person without abducting them, it's just insane.
Well Chairperson, we can argue about that.  I will tell you, that's as easy as falling out of a tree.

No, no, let us rather approach it this way.
	Mr Robertshaw, were you part of the discussions when it became, or when the unit became aware that Betty was now under suspicion that she's co-operating with your unit?
They reported to me that there was a chance of her being compromised, Mr Chairperson.  They did discuss it with me, yes.
And you agreed on the strategy that she "be abducted" from Lesotho, so that those suspicions be dispelled?
I agreed that she should be brought out of Lesotho, that's correct, Chairperson.
I think that's the tenor of how you wanted to question, Mr Malindi, I don't know.

Well can I, because it's now not clear to me at all, from your last answer, because all you say you agree to was that she should be taken out of Lesotho, you haven't agreed with what the Chairperson put to you, which was that she be "abducted" from Lesotho. (in inverted commas)
Well if it's "abducted" (in inverted commas), I agree with you, that's correct Chairperson.
Thank you, now we're on the same ...

Thank you, Chairperson.
	I'm going to put to you the difficulty that I have with this approach, which I've put to Mr Jagga before.  That Betty Boom is collected from wherever she was collected, in broad daylight, and then she's taken to Ladybrand.  There was a risk that somebody could have seen her being taken away, is it not so?

And then after spending about a week with her in Ladybrand, she's taken back into Lesotho.  Was that act not an act that's defeating the purpose of having a secure informer within the ANC?  Just in case she was seen jumping into your car voluntarily and so on.
Chairperson, we'd received no report from any other informer whatsoever that she had been, in the first place, missing, and in the second place, that she'd been abducted or seen in our presence.
So what you mean is that your informers didn't see you take her away from Lesotho?

That's not what I mean, Chairperson.  What I'm trying to answer is that we had no information to say that anybody had seen her in our presence, or that it was believed that she was working with us during the time that she was with us.  It seemed perfectly safe to us to take her back to Lesotho.
And she would have a good explanation for her absence for a week, if she had to give such an explanation to members of her unit and members of the higher organs?

Chairperson, she was the Commander of the Free State Machinery, she didn't have to answer to anybody in Lesotho.  If she - it must have occurred on many occasions that these operatives would disappear from time to time and it wouldn't be questioned, especially if she's in charge of the cell, her cell.  She was the person in charge, she could have given any answer if she asked - well she could have handled the situation.

And then you later learnt that she is being suspected within - let me start by saying, Chairperson, after she was recruited in Lesotho and agreed to cooperate with you, before the abduction, you did learn that she's being suspected of co-operating with you.  Is it not so?
That was reported to me, that's correct Chairperson.
So in other words, it means she was being watched herself and she had to report to someone.

I don't know if it means that, Chairperson, I don't know if she was being watched by anybody, perhaps she was just seen by somebody speaking to her handlers.  I don't know the circumstances regarding what brought about the whole issue of her being, perhaps being seen in the company of some of our members.

She must have been seen with her handlers and word got to the ANC that she's been seen with some strange people and there were suspicious and that is why you had to stage this abduction.  Do you agree with me so far?
She could have been seen.  As I've said, I don't know the exact circumstances which led up to this.

Can I just interpose?
	As far as you can recall, what was the nature of the compromise, of the extent to her being compromised?

Mr Chairperson, as far as I can remember, and honestly it is vague, I can't remember clearly, I think the gist of the thing is that there was a possibility that she could have been compromised because of being seen in the company of Mr Jagga and Mr Jantjie, but that's the only thing I can ...
And do you have any recollection of by whom she was being suspected?
You don't remember that sort of detail?
I can't remember that detail, Chairperson.
You see, the evidence we've heard is that when she was on the farm she in fact confirmed that there were suspicions about her.  You must have debriefed her on the farm.
I didn't debrief her at all, Chairperson, I wasn't involved in her debriefing or anything to that nature.
That's what they said, they said the two of them were the only ones that debriefed her.  Did you debrief any of the others?
Well what discussions did you have with them, individually or together?

Well hardly any discussions with them as a group.  I'd find out, ask after their well-being, find out what they needed, I'd visit them occasionally on the farm.  I wasn't on the farm all the time, Chairperson, I had other duties to do.
So when Thulo says you and Jantjie and - you pronounce it Yaya, do you?
Yes.  When you and Jantjie and Jagga went into the room, just the three of you and he was left outside, you weren't part of a debriefing at that stage, what were you part of?

If I went into the room - I can't recall it like that, Mr Chairperson, it could have happened like that, but it wasn't that I was being part of the debriefing party.  If I'd gone into the room with them, it could have been so.  But I wasn't involved in any debriefing of either, any of them.
You see that was his evidence, that he was left out and you were part of that and he went on to describe it as questioning, interrogation, or other things like that.
That's what he said.  I heard him say that, Chairperson.
So you say you weren't part of that, you were simply enquiring as to their well-being, etcetera?
Yes, there was nothing, there was no reason for me to get involved in any debriefing at all.
Sorry Mr Malindi, I've interposed long enough I think.

Thank you, Chairperson.
	Mr Robertshaw, I'm sorry if I'm making you repeat an answer that you have already given.  What was the purpose of then fetching Betty Boom from Lesotho and taking her to Ladybrand?

It was, in the first place, because of the threat that existed that she could be compromised and secondly as well, was to enable her handlers to fully debrief her on all the information that she had, which takes a long time, it's not a question of getting that sort of information in an hour or half an hour or so, it takes a long time to debrief somebody about all the information that they have got, which wasn't, you couldn't do it in Lesotho.  Especially a person of the profile of Betty Boom.

Well then the act of taking her into Ladybrand did not serve to limit or reduce the suspicions, it must have served to increase the suspicion that she was a doubtful cadre of the ANC?  I mean taking her away for about a week.
I suppose that's a matter of opinion, Mr Chairperson, I don't think so.

And then you heard the evidence of Jantjie and Jagga that how easy it was for them to recruit Betty Boom, she complained that she was not getting financial support from the ANC and that just opened the doors for them to recruit her as an informer.
And you heard that she was tired of the struggle?
I heard that as well, Chairperson.
I heard that as well, Chairperson.

You've already indicated that Nomasonto was highly - Betty Boom was a highly placed person in MK and in order to deal with her you needed enough time and so on, is that recognition of the fact that she's a highly placed person in MK?
She was a highly placed in MK, Chairper-son.
Why would such a highly placed person in MK, make it so public that she was disgruntled within the ANC, she wants out?
Chairperson, I'm not in a position to answer why she would it public, but it was made public by her.

Because the point that I want to make is that a soldier in a liberation army, if they showed those tendencies that they wanted to desert for the reasons that have been given by Jantjie and Jagga, that act would have been a stupid act on their part, because they wouldn't be trusted as loyal soldiers, isn't it so?
I don't follow completely, perhaps I'm - I don't follow exactly what you're saying now.
What I'm saying is that a highly trained, highly placed soldier of MK would hardly desert the army for the reasons that have been given by Jantjie.  Do you agree with me?
No, I can't speak for the person's reasons as to why they want to do a thing like that.

It's happened before, it's happened on a number of occasions that people have turned away from the ANC and given information.  This wouldn't be the first case that this has ever happened.  Mainly it's because of the lack of money.  When these people - I'm not using a, doing it collectively, but you get individuals that would do it for money.  The actual motivation behind their thoughts and so on, I can't tell you.

What I'm finding improbable is that such a highly placed person is recruited whilst in Lesotho, no force is used, she voluntarily comes across into Ladybrand, she agrees to continue to work for you.  A day after, another person is fetched, Nomasonto, she immediately agrees to work with you.  A day after, another person is fetched, Tax, he agrees with you.  A whole unit of highly trained cadres of MK, turns against the ANC just like that, is unbelievable.
Perhaps it sounds unbelievable, but that's what happened, Chairperson.

You know we have heard a lot of - firstly, to say you're correct, there were people who turned their backs on the ANC, but on different grounds.  We have heard how askaris were turned to work for the Security Forces, but we also were told about the amount of pressure exerted on them to work as askaris for the Security Forces.  And I think what Mr Malindi is driving at is that with these three it's merely an approach, to these four it's merely an approach and everything just works hunky-dory.
Mr Chairperson, it happened like that you know, I don't know how to answer the question.
Well maybe to refer to what Eugene de Kock once said, he said ...(intervention)
